Hell bound: A Vacation From Hell by Kathy Dinisi is a great zombie apocalypse novella. It is a short read; however, I would have finished in one day, but I just recently got out of the hospital, hence it took me a few days to read. I WON THIS E-book in return for an honest review. Now, onto my review! I feel that if this novella was re-edited, thoroughly looked through, and more descriptive, and her characters had more life in them, then I would rate this book a 5 star. There were many grammar errors, for example: "stifle gas" when it should be "siphon gas". One phrase that stuck out like a sore thumb, that loved being said throughout the entire book was, "on the floor", used when someone had fallen. It should have not been used to speak of the outdoors grounds in this way, but instead, she should have wrote, "I fell on the hot sandy dessert ground" or "I fell on the hot sand", as well as "on the hot pavement", when speaking of the asphalt ( parking lot), etc. These would have been more descriptive, than "on the floor," when you speak of outdoors. It would have helped the story flow better. Also, misused words, such as, "A heard of them chasing us", should have been, "A herd of them chasing us." I could name more grammar errors; however, I don't like being nit-picky in my reviews, because the review is supposed to be about the actual story; if it was good or not. The plot, the guts of the story is a modern day twist of what a zombie apocalypse would be like in true reality. I actually like this, because it gets you thinking of "what if?" Sam, the nurse, who first sees a patient is said to have "rabies". Then the rabies spreads quickly from one person to another, and so forth. It quickly evolves into making the infected people more powerful, strong zombie-like person(s), and very intelligent beings. This is a brilliant idea on how zombies could come about in this modern real life time novella.Sam is married to Mathew; he surprises her with a vacation for the two of them to The Grand Canyon, without their two sons for some much special romance time for these two; however, their vacation they had longed for, turns into zombies chasing them! They meet up with Kat one of the employees at their hotel they were staying at during the attack on the train ride. Kat decides to go with them instead of staying and waiting for her sister to pick her up there at her place of work. This was a great add of this character in this novella. Kat helps to bring the main characters together in the story.I enjoyed seeing the zombies start to come to "life" in the novella, meaning one talks back to Sam and one of the zombies in the beginning, they begin to realize he is actually following/chasing them. This is definitely something new with zombies. I like this, because it's a different take on how zombies are. One of my favorite parts of the novella was the guy on the radio, Steve, who had just lost his wife, Gina to a zombie. I loved how he was being the "lone survivor" with information for any other survivors. By adding this character, it helps to see where the story is going. I hope she continues to keep him in the next book! I am looking forward to reading the second book, so we can find out where their boys and her parents are; if they are ok or not. I'm also hoping the grammar is much better in the second story. Either way, I do like this new modern twist if zombies, because it does add more descriptive ways of how zombies could be in real life. Who knows Kathy Dinisi might be on to something and we should prepare ourselves for intelligent zombies, instead of one track mind zombies! Happy reading!!

***This could contain things that some may consider spoilers. I typically do do write reviews that will spoil any part of a book, but I will probably mention a few things that some could possibly consider a spoiler.*** I am going to start with the bad, why exactly I didn't give this 5 stars. I think proofreading and editing are very important. There are a lot of mistakes in this book. From using the wrong words (for example: heard when it should have been herd, site/sight, and to/too..just a few) to apparently not even realizing that the wrong word is even being used. After two times of seeing that the characters had "stifle gas" out of cars I realized that the author must not realize that the word is actually SIPHON. Or that the sun was DECOMPOSING bodies, not DEPOSING. I will say that I did laugh when a character said, "Geese, stop yelling at me" (that is a shortened version but the point was that they meant "Jeez"). I know all of this may seem nitpicking to some, but when you read so many books that are carefully written and edited, mistakes likes this stick out like a sore thumb. To me they are a distraction. So that is why I could not give this five stars, which I would have if all the errors were not present. So now on to the actual story. I read all kinds of books and here lately I have read a lot of within this genre. I will say that this was one of the more interesting takes on the "zombie" genre that I have came across. I am really interested in seeing how this story ends. I like how this all started from apparently Rabies and that the characters aren't just dealing with mindless zombies that they can escape from and then not have to worry about them. I think it adds a lot of intrigue and potential to this story and it leaves you wondering what is going to happen next. I do think we need to see more character development. At the end of the book, you still don't really know very much about the characters other than little bits and pieces. You don't really feel a connection to the characters by the time you are finished. However, I do think it was a good story and I do want to know how it ends. I do think it is worth reading and giving book 2 another chance.

1st let me say this book could be fantastic if polished up and a good formatter/editor was used. I really wanted to love this book. It had great promise but the characters were boring me quite literally and the story line was so simple you could easily see how it would end within the first few pages. The best character in the book was the radio guy I wish more of him was in it. This story really does have potential to be great but more time needed to be put in it. I've read so many zombie genre themed books nothing in this book made it special.Then let's talk about the formatting.....One problem is the chapter boxes were misplaced throughout the book and then at about 77% it went into block mode where what was written was in a square block and just plain horrible when I tint the pages to make reading easier on my eyes. These are simple formatting mistakes but quite frustrating to a reader.Maybe I would've loved this book more if the characters had more "life" to them and the story line was more involved. I truly hate giving any book a 3 star rating but feel this novella was just slapped together.

All for family!!Matthew and Samantha finally get the mini vacation of their dreams. A three day trip to the Grand Canyon. Who wouldn't drop the kids off and run? But fate picks that exact time to drop a zombie apocalypse in their laps. Now instead of enjoying themselves they are in a race with zombie hordes to make it back to their kids safely. The storyline in this book is really good. There is just enough action and it kept me interested. There are several grammatical errors such as word tense or wrong wording (like using feels instead of fills) but it doesn't distract the reader from the overall story. Samantha is a nurse. Being a nurse myself I would have liked that to have a stronger presence in the book. It's like they mentioned she was a nurse and then the apocalypse happened and she forgot how to be a nurse. Hopefully it comes into play in the future installments of this series. All in all this is definitely a must have for anyone Lompoc lover. And I personally can't wait to continue the story to find out what happens.

Hell Bound: A Vacation from Hell is a quick, action packed read. This book had me sitting on the edge of my seat and screaming at the characters to RUN!!!!!! I was sucked into the story and felt the suspense and anxiety with Matthew, Sam, and Kat. The reaction of the “public” was realistic in my opinion and kept things fluidly moving along while keeping me interested. Once the action begins it does not end, even on the last page. The constant action kept me reading until the very end because I wanted to know what was going to happen! There were grammar problems, but in no way did it distract or detract from my enjoyment of this book. I highly recommend this book to everyone who enjoys an action packed adventure.

My first book like this, I couldn't put it down!!!Sam busts her butt working as a nurse in the hospital. Her husband is taking her on a relaxing three day vacation. But, right before she's off her shift, a gunshot victim is on its way in. When they start working on him, he goes crazy. Once they get him knocked out, thinking he's on drugs, they notice some odd things that resemble rabies. After dropping their kids off, they are finally on their way. A train ride in the Grand Canyon. But a mile into the trip all hell breaks loose. ZOMBIES!!! Now they have to get supplies and try to get back to the kids. But it's spreading fast, and the zombies are getting smart....

Kathy Dinisi this is a great start to an exciting fast paced zombie series. "Hell Bound: A Vacation from Hell" by Kathy Dinisi is a good zombie read. The formatting and editing could use a bit of polishing up, but the story is there and it is entertaining. It's a good story with strong promise. Once it's all cleaned up, I believe Ms. Dinisi will have a nice novella and series going. I do look forward to the continuation and seeing what happens next. Enjoy fellow zombie enthusiasts!

Sam and Mathew finally get a chance to go on a train ride to the Grand Canyon alone leaving their two kids back in California, When a zombie apocalypse breaks out. The couple must try to fight their way back to California to see if their kids are still alive, In this harrowing story of love and survival in a world that is crumbling by death and destruction. Follow Sam and Matthew through their struggle to reunite with their children
